artist: Artist: Georges Adéagbo; Printer: Edizioni CTL, Hamburg, Germany; Photographer: Stephan Köhler; Publisher: Edizioni CTL, Hamburg, Germany
description: white soft wove paper cover; semi-transparent pages with photographic reproductions in black and white of handwriting, people, newspapers; text; advertisements; bound volume; lender's archive #216
inscription:
Inscribed in pencil on colophon: \"[_]eu serait l\'art, et que deviendrait l\'art, si le-contenu de l\'art, ne fait pas voir la vérité\"...\'

Also inscribed with indecipherable signature
markings:
Numbered on colophon page: No 15
Watermark: A on inside flap, front and back
medium: Xerox photocopies on translucent cream paper; bound volume
provenance: William P. Kosmas, London, England (d. 2017); Estate of William P. Kosmas, Minneapolis; given to MIA, 2018.
signed: signed in pencil on colophon: Georges Adéagbo
text: Beninese artist Georges Adéagbo produced this irreverent artist’s book as a parallel presentation of The Story of the Lion, an elaborate installation he displayed at the 1999 Venice Biennale, a global contemporary art exposition, where he was awarded the Prize of Honor. Like the installation, the book juxtaposes images and texts from Africa with those from European countries that had once been involved in the colonization of Africa or other forms of foreign adventurism as a way to reinterpret historical accounts. The history presented in Adéagbo’s book is constantly shifting, plural, nonhierarchical, and subversive.
title: Pour les Collectioneurs d'Oeuvres d'Art: Monument Symbolique d'Allemagne (for "The Story of the Lion")
